These amazing pictures of spectacular views may look like they were taken on a paragliding trip but there's a unique twist.
This is parahawking, a novel new sport for adrenaline junkies that gives them the chance to soar through the skies with birds by their side.
Adam Gerber, 25, captured these incredible snapshots in Pokhara, Nepal, which is currently the only place in the world to offer the daredevil activity.
Scroll down for video
Adam Gerber puts some chicken on his glove to attract the hungry vulture while paragliding in Nepal
These amazing pictures of spectacular views may look like they were taken on a paragliding trip - but there's a unique twist
Adam Gerber, 25, captured these incredible snapshots in Pokhara, Nepal, which is currently the only place in the world to offer the daredevil activity
Adam, from Philadelphia, US, said: 'I've been hang gliding before, but this was my first experience in a paraglider and of course the first time I flew with a bird!
'I actually have a big fear of heights and flying, but I was so focused on the spectacular views and the insane fact that I was flying with an Egyptian vulture while feeding him mid-flight that I had no time to be scared.'

The birds, a team of Egyptian vultures and black kites, are all specially trained to soar alongside the paragliders.
One bird flies at a time, soaring with up to three paragliders.
Adam said: 'One at a time, we rotate holding out a piece of chicken.

Despite Adam, from Philadelphia, US, admitting he has a 'fear of heights' this was one opportunity he couldn't pass up on
Adam admitted any fears he has while undertaking the activity were subsided when the vulture began its swoop in
'The bird swoops in, lands on your arm, eats the chicken and takes off again in flight.
'The one I flew with is named Bob.
'The whole thing honestly felt too surreal to be real!'
The exact moment the bird opened up its beak to swoop for the food was captured by the daredevil paraglider
The bird claws onto Adam and tastes some chicken in the skies high above Nepal
Invented by avian expert Scott Mason to highlight the plight of Asia's endangered vultures, parahawking combines ancient falconry methods with the modern techniques of paragliding, where both parties use rising currents of warm air to glide high above the land.
'Birds of prey are able to gain height and fly long distances without flapping their wings,' explains Mason.
'We as paragliders harness their natural ability to conserve energy by following them as we fly.'
Asia's vultures are virtually on the brink of extinction due to a drug called Diclofenac, an anti-inflammatory drug commonly administered to sick and dying livestock across Asia which is poisonous to vultures.
When the birds feed from animal carcasses that have been treated with Diclofenac, it causes renal failure and death.
The White Backed Vulture, The Slender Billed Vulture and the Long Billed Vulture have declined 99.9 per cent in the last 15 years, meaning 40 million birds have died.
'Vultures are often misunderstood and have a rather unsavory image,' says Mason.
'By using vultures for Parahawking we hope to change our perceptions of them. Parahawking is our unique and innovative contribution to help prevent the potential extinction of this important species.'
